review_title: Excellent for your resume and work life balance. Inferior for professional development.
pros: The organization is established and has a lot of standards for operating. Follow the rule book and you will do well.
cons: No room for growth. There are not many positions available on the team causing it to be very top heavy and the team then operates without a clear direction. The organization is not diverse (racially or experience/background) and it does not create equitable opportunities for people of color. A person of color with a decade of experience will have the same title as someone with no formal education or relevant professional experience. POCs are also not promoted at the same rate as their white counterparts. Their DEI work is a facade, there is no substance behind it because hey are not educating themselves enough and again not creating true equity. It is performative and checking A BOX (not even boxes). Salaries are not competitive despite the organization’s size, they are not enough to allow employees to live comfortably in the area. And there are many after hours events - although fun, the long days begins to take a toll when you are not compensated well or for extra time. No formal off boarding process. Incorrect information was provided and accounts immediately cut off, made it difficult to close your accounts how you would like and obtain items you were told were yours to keep.

review_title: Great mission and great people but not so great culture and lacks commitment to diversity
pros: A great opportunity to be a part of a great mission that serves a great community. The science and research teams are top notch especially in the lab and the work done by the Foundation truly makes a great life altering impact to the lives of those living with CF. Any employee will gain great experience in their respective space.
cons: Even though the organization as been around for over 20 years, it lacks maturity in business matters and expertise. Senior leadership needs some improvement in regards to their ability to make decisions and communicate well. I do believe the Foundation wants to be more diverse but like many companies on this topic it is the blind leading the blind and they tend to seem to be more focused on "optics" versus including true diversity such as diversity of thought. Too many people have been their way too long, all look the same, think the same and therefore lack perspective. With those dynamics, it is hard to say that the company will truly be able to commit to the mission around diversity the way it truly needs to.

pros: Great organization Amazing people to work with Great work/life balance
cons: Lack of career growth structure Lack of resources to support career growth

pros: Incredible people and an incredible cause that is truly making a difference in the lives of those with CF.
cons: Limited areas of growth and opoortunities

pros: Great progress advancing the mission and great plans for continuing progress across the organization! The culture is strong. Some of the smartest, nicest people work here.
cons: The pace can be really difficult with multiple projects going on at once and an ever changing priority list.

pros: Amazing organization that puts its money where its’ mouth is. Money raised goes towards mission. Competitive salaries. Amazing benefits that they keep adding to to help all employees with work-life balance. Supportive co-workers with an inclusive culture.
cons: Event season is crazy busy and depending on the area, there is 1-3 staff doing everything.

review_title: A Disastrous Breach of Diversity Promises and a Toxic Haven of Discrimination
pros: The hybrid office schedule offered the flexibility to work both remotely and in-person.
cons: I am compelled to share my utterly disheartening experience with CFF, a so-called champion of diversity and inclusivity. The facade this company projects is a cruel deception that masks the deep-seated discrimination and racism rampant within its walls. Regrettably, my time there revealed an organization that not only fails to follow through on its diversity pledge but perpetuates a toxic culture that fosters discrimination against people of color (POC). From the moment I stepped foot into their office, it was abundantly clear that their purported commitment to diversity was nothing more than an empty marketing ploy. While they may boast about their diversity initiatives and virtue signal to the world, the reality for POC employees is a stark contrast. Discriminatory practices are not only prevalent but seemingly encouraged within the company's hierarchy. Racism thrives within the very fabric of CFF's culture. The toxic environment I encountered on a daily basis was suffocating. POC employees are subjected to demeaning stereotypes, exclusionary practices, and unequal opportunities for growth and advancement. It is a soul-crushing experience to witness colleagues with less merit and talent receive promotions solely based on their race, while POC individuals are consistently overlooked and undervalued. What is even more disheartening is the complete lack of accountability and action from CFF's management. Despite numerous complaints and reports filed by POC employees regarding discriminatory practices, their voices fall on deaf ears. The HR department, supposedly responsible for addressing such concerns, remains complicit in this abhorrent behavior by turning a blind eye and failing to take any meaningful action. The "diversity pledge" is an utter sham, an illusion designed to deceive potential employees and appease public scrutiny. The company's commitment to diversity is merely lip service without any genuine effort to create an inclusive workplace. It is an insult to the intelligence of POC individuals who hoped to find a supportive and equitable environment at CFF. My experience there was nothing short of a nightmare. The psychological toll of enduring a workplace rife with racism and discrimination is immeasurable. The false promises, the lack of accountability, and the complicity of the management have left me deeply disillusioned. I implore anyone considering employment at CFF to think twice before subjecting themselves to this toxic cesspool. There are undoubtedly organizations out there that genuinely value diversity and prioritize inclusivity. Sadly, this is not one of them.

pros: Nice people to work with
cons: Salary could be better than it is

pros: Benefits, salary and cause are notable.
cons: If you are a lower tier employee you are subject to management abuse. From gaslighting to unfeeling attitude about employee welfare.

job_title: Associate Executive Director in Washington, DC
pros: Making tremendous progress in research for a cure.
cons: No cons to add at this time.

pros: Makes an effort in prioritizing employees
cons: A lot of work without appropriate compensation

pros: Hybrid schedule and early release Fridays
cons: Pay and direct management could be better

pros: The CF Foundation is a great place to work, with an incredible mission, talented staff and a dedicated community.
cons: Truly no complaints, I would recommend working at the CF Foundation to anyone.

review_title: Huge disconnect, no reason to stay
pros: Great place if you want to work a second job to support yourself while working to the bone with little recognition, but hey 1pm Fridays!! Box of pens as thank you during Covid, probably something better now.
cons: No incentive to stay, non competitive pay, no overtime, toxic national office. What does HR even do here? Ops team has high turnover while development staff get promotions for not doing events, not hitting budgets, but I guess it’s good if you need maternity leave while having a kid.

pros: great work-life balance for employees
cons: No real opportunity or room for growth

review_title: Field burnout & lack of incentive to stay
pros: Great mission, 1 pm Friday’s, great community. Did not do layoffs during COVID.
cons: Plenty of opportunities for growth (if you’re willing to not get paid for the extra work you’re assuming.) Pay is not competitive and negotiation is not an option if you’re a current employee. There’s a huge disconnect between the National and chapter offices. Field staff is worked to the bone and held to unrealistic financial expectations. CEO and upper management have no clue what’s happening in the field and don’t seem to care

review_title: Toxic Work Environment, Burn Out, Etc.
pros: 1pm Fridays, and decent benefits.
cons: Toxic work environment in chapter offices among colleagues and management. Burnout. Pay isn't great and chapter management lacks leadership skills completely.

review_title: Great mission, leadership has room to improve
pros: Mission-driven organization with employees who truly care about the mission and finding a cure for CF
cons: Lack of opportunity unless you’re in the established “boys club.” Appear to be committed to DEI efforts, but it is quite clear that this was a jump on the bandwagon move with no tangible actions to show that this is true intentions. The recent change to make employees come back in the office 2 days a week, after working remotely for 2.5 years, is also disappointing and expect many employees will leave for remote opportunities.

pros: Provides meaningful work in support of finding a cure.
cons: Some unrealistic expectations from national office.

pros: Mission focused. Passionate to find a cure for cystic fibrosis.
cons: Too many internal policies hinder employees abilities to actually do their job and fundraise.

pros: Stable, good compensation, implementing WorkDay for most business functions (Payroll, HR, Accounting)
cons: Need to do a better job at getting people to work together and rely less on technology to solve people problems

pros: The CFF is a fantastic organization to work for. The benefits are great and the entire organization is very mission focused. Leadership is visible and easy to engage. There is a real sense of community.
cons: Immediate opportunity for advancement may be a bit limited depending on where you are within the organization.

pros: Great cause to be part of.
cons: HQ staff should get out to field offices more.

review_title: Very rewarding work but overloaded with priorities all the time
pros: 401k and match by company, rewarding feeling/work, medical, dental, vision benefits, employer paid additional life insurance.
cons: Overloaded with work and priorities that come down from the National office from every department.

pros: Everyone working at the Foundation is working towards a singular mission. Compared to other jobs in information security, this one keeps us on our toes but is not a terribly stressful job. Additionally, there has not been an issue in getting leadership to understand and support investments in security, technology or otherwise.
cons: The regular challenges of a non-profit still exist, e.g., the "iron-fist" sometimes seen in private companies is a bit softer here. As a result, we sometimes spend inordinate amounts of time messaging things that should merely be dictated by fiat, if you will.

review_title: Organization with a good infrastructure, but stifled by bureaucracy
pros:
Good salary, benefits, and enough staff to feel like you can get your work done within the work week.
Great people
They are trying to listen to staff feedback, with staff surveys
cons:
It takes a long time to make changes at CFF. Because CFF is very concerned about their brand, important changes are happening at a leisurely pace, despite the urgency. There are too many individuals that need to approve or review deliverables.
Poor opportunities for growth. While they offer opportunities for professional development, there are very little opportunities for promotions. Meanwhile, the leadership continue to get promotions and make a substantial salary (refer to their 990 form on the website). The gap in salaries between those doing the work and those making decisions is quite large.

pros: Great environment to work in while supporting individuals living with cystic fibrosis and their families, the current leadership has done an incredible job guiding the organization through the pandemic and keeping its employees and the community safe while also taking action to address becoming more inclusive workplace. The time off (vacation, holidays, sick, personal, volunteer) policy is really good plus they offer early release summer Fridays to all staff.
cons:
Not a lot of room for upward mobility
Concerns voiced to upper management and HR tend to get brushed under the rug versus actively addressed

pros: Friendly environment and great team
cons: no cons in my opinion

pros:
* decent salary for a non-profit
* benefits package pretty good
* great cause
cons: Even if competitive, pay is still not that high for some of the chapter staff and probably Bethesda staff too

pros: Fellow staff members, volunteers and supporters. Flexible work environment
cons: No cons to offer, pleased to work for the CFF family two different times throughout my career and proud of their progress towards a cure!

review_title: Working here is like a fire drill
job_title: Development Director in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Causal attire for working in the office
cons:
Long hours without much notice
The volunteers run the org at the local level
Management at local level is not good

pros:
Not enough room for growth. Manager is not hiring new people for those who have left and I'd piling on extra work onto people who are overworked (no promotions for this). 

I enjoyed working here until this occurred.
cons: Not much room for growth

pros: Lots of ambition across the organization. Recent addition to leadership bringing new level of maturity.
cons: More work needs to be done on organizational infrastructure to support the kind of the pace of work CFF is aspiring to.

pros:
-Clear mission and active community surrounding the organization's work. 
-Responsible for many aspects of the disease, so it's interesting to have such a complete view of the industry and system that supports people with CF. Trying to do better with culture and DEI.
-They have a lot of money so salaries are good for a non-profit org.
cons:
-Absolutely NO intention to ever promote people or even given them raises -- you are locked in as soon as you start, so do not ever expect to advance or even get more money than a cost of living increase. 
-Poor management attempting to be disguised by a bunch of corporate speak. 
-Focus on systems and processes instead of what people actually need. 
-Hiring people simply because they have medical degrees or clinical experience to run teams and departments that are not about medical research or clinical care. 
-Absolutely a "popular kids" environment, where if you don't get on someone's good side quickly you are relegated to second-tier status as an employee who is regularly dismissed and ignored. 
-The organization is still not self-aware enough to admit its own responsibility in failings around DEI in the community at large and in the workplace.

pros: Same as all other company
cons: No use of this box

pros: Easy work environment, good people, flexible
cons: Hard advancing writhing your role

pros: Great working environment and benefits
cons: No cons for this job.

pros: Clear mission with engaged community
cons: Retention of quality talent and lack of career development

pros: Great mission. Leader in non profit models. Inclusive and diverse. Great benefits and work/life balance is encouraged. Remote and hybrid schedules available.
cons: Not enough opportunities for advancement.

pros: Good job satisfaction working here
cons: No downside I can think of

pros: Mission, caring for their employees, CEO, science backed, flexibility, work life balance
cons: Red tape, processes outdated, weekend work (if in the Field)

pros: Leadership is very thoughtful - do things right, for both people with CF and for the employees. Less total work hours than most places. Flexible. Transparent. Close to the metro. Free food all the time (in normal times). Working hard on DEI efforts.
cons: It's a non-profit, so you work hard and don't get as much salary as your for-profit peers. It can also feel cultish sometimes - with a "we're a big family" feel and lots of inspirational videos and crying. It comes from a good place, but can be uncomfortable if you don't like lots of touchy-feely stuff at work. Some teams are extremely organized and productive, others less so.

pros: More sophistication and organizational maturity with some recent additions to executive leadership.
cons: Overall, a great place so long as it stays focused on the mission.

pros: Benefits, generous time off, coworkers
cons: Upper management, ton of red tape

pros: Warm & loving volunteers, world class science
cons: Lack of transparency in leadership below CEO

job_title: Senior Development Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros: Very successful organization that has made incredible advancements.
cons: Lacks professional development and upward mobility

pros:
-Fantastic benefits
-Strongly believe in the organization's mission.
-Big push for inclusion (DEI) throughout the organization
-Great people
cons:
-Many nights and weekends
-Promotions can be slow

pros: Everyone is nice and the foundation is quite generous to its employee
cons: Not that I can think of.

review_title: It is a mission driven nonprofit
pros: The mission & the organization’s drive to meet the needs of the CF community.
cons: There are not equal opportunities for promotion.

job_title: Business Development Manager in Washington, DC
pros: Great work environment, they really take care of their employees!
cons: No cons at the moment.

pros:
CF is a very tight-knit community. You'll have family and friends and CFers come up and say thanks all the time. That was very nice.

Great medical benefits.
cons:
Completely mismanaged from the inside. Also just a lot of toxic personalities. Counterintuitive to what you'd think from a non-profit organization. 

- Co-workers were mean
- A lot of long-time donors left while I was there
- Long-time employees have basically secured tenure. They could coast and get by with little to no work/care.
- The foundation's R&D decisions are not great. Take a look at how much some therapies/treatments cost for CF families

pros: Dedicated people working hard to find a cure for CF.
cons: Spread a bit thin, trying to be many things to many people.

pros: This is an organization who truly cares about the community it serves and the staff that helps advance their mission.
cons: There are no downsides to working at the CF Foundation. It is an incredible cause and an incredible Foundation.

pros: Great Culture, Knows their values
cons: I do not believe there are any

pros: Great place to work. Cares for its employees. Lots of collaboration.
cons: None that I can think of right now.

job_title: Account Payable Specialist in Bethesda, MD
pros: Corporate perks including regular employee parties and honoring holiday time off
cons: Corporate mentality of looking at portfolio of the business instead of the individuals in front of them

pros: Values are strong, they care about employees especially during the pandemic. New bonus structure is amazing.
cons: Hard to get promotions, very structured in terms of upward mobility.

review_title: Mission-driven organization with friendly and dedicated staff
pros: I have experienced tremendous professional growth during my time at CFF, much more so than anywhere I’ve worked in the past.  My seniors give me the tools, guidance, and encouragement that I need in order to develop and be successful in my role.  The vast majority of people who work here are brilliant, creative, and friendly, and the sense of shared dedication to our mission is awesome in the truest sense of the word.  The new speaker series in which people with cystic fibrosis and their families share their stories with Foundation staff is an incredibly powerful reminder of why we do what we do.  At the more micro-level, my supervisor is very respectful of work-life balance, and is flexible on things like taking time off or working from home as needed.  Little perks like early release on Fridays during the summer and at the start of holiday weekends go a long way to sustain morale.  CFF has its quirks just like every workplace on the planet, but overall I am very happy and grateful to work here.
cons: The most pervasive problem has to do with the historical silo-ing of different programs.  You will pretty frequently find that the left hand doesn’t know what the right is doing.  However, leadership is taking steps to resolve this and to promote cross-functional collaboration and information sharing.  On a tactical note, we have some extremely cumbersome processes related to procurement, particularly of IT equipment.  It is not uncommon to have to wait several weeks for something really basic like a (standard, no-frills) monitor or keyboard.

review_title: Great Cause - Bad Leadership and Management
pros: Loved working for such a great cause and getting to know and interact with the volunteers, families and supporters. Able to see where efforts were making a difference. Management in the office was very aware and responsive to employees invidividual needs. Greatly enjoyed my co-workers in the office but was hard to see them unhappy in their jobs as well.
cons: Management is very top down from National. Try to fit all chapters into the same box giving us no control to modify events to better fit our supporters and our community. Communication from National was horrible. Directives, policies and procedures were constantly changing or being implemented before they had been finalized resulting in constant changes and corrections. Very little appreciation of staff that puts in long hours for very little pay. Pay was also way less then similar non-profit positions and raises (if you can even call it that) were a joke. No incentive to stay at the company long term because there is no process for moving up into a new position or development of staff.

pros:
-Great vacation time
-Flexibility
-Great leadership, very transparent
cons: If you're a specialist, you do not get the option to work from home. (pre pandemic)

review_title: Non Profit with a Corporate soul
pros:
Benefits/Salary
Location
Worthy cause
Work environment (treadmill desk, mother's room, free coffee and soda, personal standing desks available)
cons:
Ridiculously Clique-like (A former co-worker was actually told that showing an interest in a boss's hobbies could gain him/her more visibility and opportunity)

Favoritism (Employees with well-to-do family members receive special treatment and promotions, while employees doing the actual work are not), Brown-nosing, gossip

Extremely poor communication from Exec to Managers to Non management employees

Non-efficient, some departments (example:Operations) are bloated with too many employees doing the the same thing, where other departments are forced to be a skeleton crew, and to do more with less for years and years.

Scarce upward movement, unless it's borne from dire necessity, not as a reward for doing good, honest work. 

Poor manners from the majority of staff, unless of course they need something from you, or your specific help on a project.

High turnover rate in several departments

I've worked here 10 years, this has been my observation from my very first year on.

pros: Amazing people to work with. Comes with great benefits and other cushy perks
cons: Non-profit = low salary. Management cares too much about what your educational level is rather than what you contribute

job_title: Director of Development in Richmond, VA
pros: The Cause for the pope who need help.
cons: The upper management not listening to lower management.

pros:
Great work/life balance
CEO cares about employees
Caring company culture
cons: Not any that I can think of

pros: Coworkers are great, good work life balance, great cause
cons: Too many meetings and sometimes management can be unreasonable

review_title: Wonderful Cause, Not So Wonderful Work Environment
pros: There is no better feeling than knowing you are doing something worthwhile. The mission of the CF Foundation is a truly beautiful one. Furthermore, the Foundation is making amazing head way in curing CF. They have a wonderful set of dedicated volunteers and donors that work tirelessly alongside the staff. The best part of working at the Foundation has been interacting with CF Families and the wonderful volunteer base.
cons: The Foundation is a nonprofit,  their bottom line is to cure CF - not focus their attention on employee satisfaction. Chapter staff are given little to no support from National Executives. There is actually a deep lack of communication between the two. Chapter staff are usually small teams (which can be a pro) - that due to this, are ridiculously overworked. While you may be hired for a 9AM-5PM position - prepare yourself for long nights and even longer weekends during the months leading up to events. There is not a fondness of "overtime" so "donated" time happens quick a bit. There also can be little to no room for growth and development with the company. In fact many of our employees are expected to fill the hybrid role of two positions for the salary of one (and the lower one at that).

review_title: Great team, support, work life balance, upper management, and mission.
job_title: Development Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: All chapter dependent but all teams and employees are very supportive of each other. Values work life balance. Great mission.
cons: Lots of policies to follow. Outdated systems and procedures.

pros: Pay and benefits were good
cons: Pressure, inner turmoil within branch office, rude coworkers, unfair treatment

pros: I'd say hours, but you end up putting in SO many extra which you don't get paid for, even the daily hours are not a benefit.
cons: Workload is impossible.   Archaic systems which make tasks daunting.  They try to offer trainings via video courses but you are bombarded with them at first, which creates a situation where it's impossible to actually retain the information.   Weekly calls go over things so fast they are useless.  There is so much red tape to get through any task, you can never get anything accomplished, hence making the tasks on your plate unmanageable.  Rules change nearly weekly.  What was right a week ago is now updated and you are expected to know that and follow it with little notice or explanation.

pros: An organization that is truly raising funds for the cause.  Generous salary.  Casual workplace.  Nice office space.
cons: Where do I begin?  After working there for a few weeks, the entire portfolio changed.  Long hours, meetings with chambers, donors, new business, you’re out of the office practically everyday.  Too many training videos and not enough hands on with seasoned employees to get you up to speed.  Executive Director is hardly in the office and consistently barks orders via phone, text and email.  And, they are threatened by anyone with experience outside of how they’ve always done things.  The rest of the staff are constantly worried about doing anything wrong for fear of losing their job or being subjected to the wrath of the E.D.  It’s amazing that the office is successful under these circumstances.  If the E.D.’s supervisor or home office could see how things function, they would be in shock.  Not a pleasant experience at all.

review_title: It's impossible to get anything done with all the redtape in the IT dept.
pros: Great benefits, great work life balance
cons: The entire IT department starting from the top is useless. The new IT department have added new systems and it's impossible to get help. IT is right here in the building but to get anything done you have to go online to complete a JIRA request, now if I can't log onto your computer how are you to complete a JIRA request? The helpdesk tries to help but their hands are tied because a JIRA request has to be completed first before anything gets done. How is this more efficient or customer oriented? Employees are not able to provide any input into what works and the IT department do whatever they want and might as well walk on water! In addition, the JIRA request page sucks and it's impossible to entire the request that you want because it is limited. Talk about lost productivity!

pros: I really don't have any pros but if I had to say something...I would say the cost of parking but that still isn't bad because that is only roughly $115 per month...which is very affordable.
cons: The best way to sum this up is that they really care about their employees.  I have only been here since December 2015 and I have NO plans to go anywhere.  They are always doing something for the staff.  I love what the foundation stands for and the staff is also very friendly.  Great benefits as well...just got an email that we are going to get a half day before Memorial Day just because of our great work!  Upper management is also great to work with as well.  I'm also already moving into a different position for more growth which is really great.  Work hours are also awesome 9 - 5 pm with an hour for lunch...7 hour work days...plus some departments have flexibility on the start times.  The best thing I like about working here is that I feel like I am really part of a great group working to save lives.

review_title: If you value your sanity, look elsewhere
pros: Benefits package, days off, dress code
cons: There is no work/life balance.  They expect too much and hire too few per chapter.  Red tape makes getting anything done impossible.  Policies and procedures change monthly, sometimes weekly.  It’s impossible to keep up, even for veteran employees.  And, if you aren’t certain of which “new” is the new, don’t plan on asking your boss, she’ll bite your head off for not knowing, or make you feel horrible.

pros: The mission is so compelling. The organization is very strong financially and making break throughs ever year in finding the cure for CF. This is a nible organization that can change quickly. If fact, they make changes often. They can do this because it is a top-down organization that can quickly push a new message or program through its network.
cons: This organization is very cult-like. You must fit with their culture or you won't survive. As a top-down organization, it is not open to creative thinking or letting staff participate in setting strategy. They do pull together groups of staff and volunteers for feedback. BUT it had better be the feedback they want. If not, then that person is sort of blacklisted and not included in any future discussions. It is a high pressure operation. I have never worked for any place that fires so many people.

review_title: Great mission, making great strides for a cure.
pros: Great mission, always incorporating CF patients and families for education to employees. Friendly staff have met some of my closest friends here. Some managers that may not be your own manager help build and nurture talents. Give you opportunities to find things you like to do.
cons: Employees who start at entry level seem to have less promotions and lower salary increase even ones who have shown longevity at the foundation. Even after some time (3-5 years) still treated like entry level college students who just need a job. New recruits can come in at higher levels with more pay and leave within a year or so. The flow higher ups seem to be top heavy and a small lower level take on the load of many.

review_title: CFF is like a big family - you love it, but sometimes you hate it
pros: Flexible schedules, great benefits, strong mission, strong relationships, aggressive revenue numbers that promote a constant challenge for chapter staff, and most importantly - the people you are helping
cons: Organization leaders do not promote professional development unless it directly impacts our bottom line, career path within organization not clear and not encouraged, (Often) CFF will bring in new staff before promoting within, promotions within come with a lesser salary which lead the employee to ultimately seek other employment, training for new staff is all computer based- very outdated and ineffective, many staff members (nationwide) lack real talent and drive

job_title: Development Department in New York, NY
pros: A very good cause, helping families.  The families can be very stressed about health care, so treat them with respect and they will really show up for you!
cons: The compensation is not market rate.  They year-over-year raises don't even meet cost of living. The "commission" is not reachable as it is based on percentage growth above GOAL year-over-year, not on what you actually accomplish.  The "commission" is very small.  Your donors can be moved among offices, so you may steward a donor and have that donor moved into another staff member's territory.  You overpay for your own insurance.  You pay your own expenses and are reimbursed much later.  No budget for fundraising, so you are encouraged to let your donors treat YOU to coffees, etc. If you travel, you have to share a room or pay for yourself. Technology stuck in the 90's. Disorganized comms.

review_title: Great organization, great people, great cause
pros: My  favorite thing about the Foundation is that I get to work with an outstanding group of people in support of great cause. While it varies from department to department, I've found incredible mentors and career opportunities, and feel that I am consistently given the tools I need to do the job I've been tasked with. HR has recently rolled out a slate of expanded benefits, including parental leave and adoptions assistance.
cons: The Foundation has an incredibly meeting-heavy culture, which is complicated by our current lack of conference room space; teams are actively working on the latter, but I would like to see a movement to address the former. Teams an also be quite silo-ed, unaware of what others are doing.

review_title: Totally corporate with clueless and confrontational middle management
pros: - Curing CF is obviously difficult. The Foundation is the leader in the search for a cure. Knowing this makes you feel somewhat rewarded.
cons:
Where to begin? Besides the middle/upper management being absolutely unprofessional and rude to their entry level employees, there is a severe disconnect between departments. I have never worked in an environment where collaboration and teamwork was so vehemently discouraged. 

Additionally, getting anything done that requires management approval takes months to accomplish. There are many managers here who needlessly assign tasks and edits as busywork - even if the final product was ready seven drafts ago. 

Insofar as to "rudeness," multiple managers and middle managers have, as pressured by their bosses, micromanaged to the point of offensiveness. If you hired me for a position, some leeway to actually fulfill it would be appreciated.

review_title: Director of Development, special events coordinator
job_title: Director of Development; Special Events Coordinstor in Richmond, VA
pros: Knowing you are helping promote awareness, sharing science and trying to raise money to provide a cure for the amazing patients and their families.
cons: It is overrun with senior staff who need to retire who maintain  absurd and impossible goals while expecting chapter staff to sacrifice their time, money and talent while not being even close to industry competitive with salary or benefits. It is cliquey and their are those who will look to get rid of people who have experience and ideas. Nothing is safe with HR. We lost 2 EDs and 6 others while I was there in my 2 years.

pros: Great mission. CF community is well informed and involved. Fundraising dollars go to pharmaceutical pipeline to develop lifesaving drugs. Many accomplishments have been made through business model. Many caring  staff.
cons: top tier management is terrible, top down style, bad communication and self serving in some cases. professional training is needed for those senior folks that have held positions for long term. turf battles are the norm, negatively affect those who are trying to get work done and bring new ideas to the table. mid-level folks really struggle with leadership.

review_title: The CF Foundation Is a Worthy Cause, But Does Not Consider It's Valuable Junior Staff
pros:
The cause is important - to save lives.
The money is spent efficiently.
People who work here tend to be well-educated.
cons:
They do not tend to promote from within the organization. 
The Foundation is very hierarchical. 
Senior staff are not particularly friendly with each other.
Communication between departments and at different levels is very limited.

review_title: If you get a good manger to work for, this place is an absolute dream.
pros: Highly-knowledgable, extremely talented and friendly staff.  Organizational leadership was strong and created  a welcoming climate to work in. Working was interesting and constantly evolving. People really respect one another and not only value differing opinions, but seek them out in an honest and welcoming manner.
cons: High turn-over, Wasn't clear how one was supposed to advance in career, get a raise or earn a promotion. A good amount of strife and conflict between departments. Conflict resolution was handed poorly and most times was nonexistent.

review_title: Great organization which requires hard work for little pay and recognition
pros: To serve and work with those afflicted with this terrible disease and to increase their life expectancy by raising money for important research.
cons: You work very hard managing multiple events for low pay. Performance evals and procedures to promote from within the region are inconsistant and unfair. Expectations to make budget are very high.

review_title: Great organization, if a bit bare bones at times.
pros: The mission, the staff, and the CF community.  It's easy to feel inspired at work when you're surrounded by people who have bought into the cause so significantly.  Likewise, the families and patients are extremely supportive and appreciative of the Foundation.  Internally, most departments seem to do what they can to make working there a good experience.  Most people generally like their coworkers and their job and you don't have to work for the organization for too long before you start to feel like you're seeing the benefit of the work you're doing with the patients.  The organizational leadership is also very good at keeping staff in the loop about new developments and helping everyone to understand where they fit into the bigger picture so that no one feels like their department or job isn't valuable.
cons: Typical for a non-profit, you will be paid under-market.  The company prides itself on how little overhead it has, putting the vast majority of its dollars into research.  The downside is that it also can feel like penny-pinching over small things.  The corporate culture of the organization is also ironically very outdated.  Everything is structured to run like a 1960s era bank with ultimate leadership coming from the executives and little room for influence the further down the line you go.   Also, although I didn't experience this, many of colleagues had significant problems advancing.  Many people stayed at the same position without any advancement for years even when they were taking on greater responsibilities and turning in good work.  Lots of people told me when they left it was more because they didn't see a pathway going forward in their career than for something like more money at another place.

pros: The CF Foundation is dedicated and passionate about its mission to find a cure and improve the lives of those struggling with the disease. On a corporate level, they also have created opportunities to emphasize work life balance.
cons: While being employed at the Foundation for about 2 years, I felt abused, undermined and manipulated by my supervisor. I was not the first one to leave  due their inappropriate, irrational behavior. However, the situation has not been acknowledged or rectified, which continues to make the office a toxic environment to work in despite the amazing purpose of the job!

review_title: Highly innovative, results-oriented nonprofit, best in class, 1st to develop pioneering "venture philanthropy" biz model
pros:
-Highly innovative
-Entrepreneurial culture
-First charity to develop "venture philanthropy" business model recognized by Forbes, Fortune, Harvard Business School, Wall Street Journal and the New York Times
-Developed drug to treat 4% of patients with disease; approved by FDA in 2012
-Very results oriented
-Very efficent; 90 cents of every dollar goes to medical research
-Relentless in drive to find a cure for cystic fibrosis
cons:
-Extremely intense and taxing pace of work
-Some employees become burned out
-A very atypical nonprofit -- runs very much like a "for profit" (also  "pro")
-Very bottom-line driven (this is also a "pro")

review_title: Great Foundation, Great Cause, Not-So-Great Management Practices
pros: Excellent, dedicated staff. CFF is an organization that is truly gravitating towards a cure for the disease.
cons: There is a thin line between "compensated time" and a "donation of your time" that is often abused. There is also a constant revolving door with staff making it difficult to focus on your job responsibilities alone.

review_title: Good place to work, improvements are being made
pros: Great benefits, work life balance and employees are nice. Pay is pretty good.
cons: Young employees who want promotions when they have no work experience to warrant a promotion. They want trophies for just doing their jobs and management caters to their winey attitudes.  Some employees get promoted immediately and frequently because there is some favoritism and some do not.

review_title: The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation is an excellent place to work for those who want to help those in need.
job_title: Special Events Coordinator in Cockeysville, MD
pros: I am proud to work here.  As a charity that has less than 10% overhead, we are giving our donors and patients the utmost respect in handling their money and treating our patients.
cons: The only downside is that we do not make a lot of money.  I could easily make more if I were to leave here and find a job in the private sector, but I know that I would not enjoy my job as much as I do here.

review_title: Great place to work (at least at the national office)
pros:
(I'd probably give the Foundation more of a 4.5 star rating but we'll round up because the future outlook is sunny and this is the best place I've worked in my career.)

The CF community is hands down one of the most inspiring groups of people you can work with. Cystic fibrosis is a horrible, life-shortening rare disease that places a heavy burden on those living with CF as well as their loved ones, yet people within the community are so uplifting, positive and strong. You will shed many tears experiencing their stories and journeys, both happy and sad. The amazing thing about being part of the Foundation is that we are making a tangible difference and changing the face of the disease by extending the life expectancy for those living with CF, investing in innovative new drugs that improve quality of life, and providing more content and community for those living with cystic fibrosis. The tangible impact the Foundation has on the disease and the lives of those living with CF is unlike any other organization I've previously worked at. You truly feel like your 9-5 is making an impact on people's lives.

The Foundation is making big efforts to improve the culture and the benefits of the organization. They recently implemented paid maternity/paternity leave, shortened the length of the work day and improved healthcare benefits for new employees. The pay is very competitive and there are many super talented, intelligent people working at the Foundation. You will learn and grow a lot working here.
cons:
There are 70-ish chapter locations and I don't think that the experience at our satellite locations is as ideal as at the national office. There's a disconnect between the Field and the rest of the organization and I think it's a super pain point of the organization that hasn't been properly addressed, and that comes down to politics. 

There are definitely politics at CFF between senior management and between departments which I think has a far-reaching impact that is felt most directly by the chapters. Internal communication and internal goals tend to be very silo'd which can cause frustration and a feeling of disconnect when everyone at the Foundation should be on the same team, with the same mission (to cure CF!) 

While many large organizations inevitably face similar issues, especially considering the major changes the Foundation has experienced in the past 3 years alone, there is definitely work to do in streamlining individual team's efforts and improving the way departments work with one another. 

Also, while the Bethesda location is easy to access and the trail behind the office is gorgeous, there is a severe lack of space for meeting rooms and new employees. And the current building is not modern and lacks many standard amenities. Not a deal breaker but we can do better.

pros:
The organization is clearly making a difference in curing a disease. As a Development person you can feel confident knowing that when you ask someone to donate that those dollars are being used efficiently. 

Being a part of a local Chapter has its benefit in the ability to create and develop events and cultivate donor relationships that are not locked into a cookie cutter format.
cons:
Feels like a general disconnect between National Office leadership and staff on the front lines. 
Very little training and career/self development plans
No clear path to promotion or raises
Feels like they could take it or leave it if you are talented and productive and a risk to leave.

review_title: Great place to work, if you like to be overworked & under appreciated
job_title: Special Events Coordinator in Charleston, SC
pros: Great cause, wonderful staff, wonderful volunteers, cool events, opportunity to learn more in an entry level position than at a major corporation, opportunity to interact with high level business execs
cons: Long hours, the volunteer is always right & you are not allowed to stand up for yourself in any way shape or form (even if everyone involved knows the volunteer is wrong or malicious) little boundaries between personal & professional life

review_title: Passionate people working for an important cause... but sometimes tripping over one another
pros:
There is a unique passion and dedication to the cause.
You meet an incredible community of patients.
The employees are very smart, proactive, and creative. 
The Foundation provides excellent resources to work with. 
The "top" executives frequently intermingled with all levels to show gratitude, recognition, and provide advice.
Accomplishments are acknowledged. 
The research is fascinating. 
The benefits are exceptional and exceed most company offerings.
cons: The "middle" leadership (directors) have difficulty communicating clearly.  They frequently give conflicting directions and the arguments and disagreements are public.

pros: It's truly the definition of a non-profit organization. The money raised really does go to science and trying to find a cure.
cons: Career development is almost non-existent. They have the ability to create newer/higher positions. They keep the existing employees at the same level, but hire non-qualified people for higher positions.

pros: Flexible schedule, Good Location, Good Benefits
cons:
Any company/organization that is being investigated by the EEOC is not a place you want to work. Not to mention an investigation by the IRS into CFF's 501(c) status. I can't say CFF didn't bring it on themselves because they did. There isn't a shred of integrity here, and it is blatantly obvious. Somebody high up angered somebody with significant gov clout. It is a shame because the patients of CFF are going to be significantly impacted by the greed of some. :( 

I wouldn't recommend anyone in the world to CFF right now, and to my fellow coworkers get out fast.

pros: The CFF is a great place to work if you are looking for a fulfilling job that challenges you and gives you room to learn and grow.  Great teamwork and collaboration - each day allows you to use your skills together with your coworkers to achieve a common goal.  Management does a good job of communicating the strategy and giving us the tools needed to succeed.
cons: We are growing at a quick pace and that can cause processes to get bottle-necked at times.

review_title: culture of excellence, inspiring mission, culture improving every day
pros: There is no question that staff really care about the mission. Strong culture of achieving excellence--staff are top in field. Staff definitely becoming more diverse, although still lots of work to be done on this front.
cons: Too much competition/drama between departments--we all have a shared mission, we should be a team. However, the culture has come very far in the past few years with changes in leadership and continues to improve with the ongoing culture initiative.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Wonderful volunteers and families involved. Great strides made in medicines to make a drastic improvement in patients with CF.
cons: ED and many top staff are difficult to work with. Tends to be clicky and one minute they like you a and the next you are an outcast. Higher ups work little and worker bees doing the real work put in the most work with little credit. Not much room for growth within organization.

pros: Helping those afflicted with such a horrible disease raise money to find a cure; flexible work environment/arrangements; summer Fridays and dress-down days
cons: Everything else: management, competitiveness within chapters; no sense or encouragement of collaboration.  Fluffing numbers, stealing donors from each other.  Horrible and dated technology.  Red tape and bureaucracy.

pros: Hands down the two best things about the Foundation are the mission and the people.  Everyone is extremely dedicated to the mission which is to cure Cystic Fibrosis.  The executive staff is approachable and visible.
cons: While there is a pay scale now which salaries are determined, those of us that were hired before it was in place have salaries that are all over the place.

review_title: We are a family and work long hours on many events so we can find a cure.
pros: Flexible work schedules, amazing families in the CF community.
cons: We are understaffed for the amount of events that we produce And have constant turnover. National does not understand the Chapter level so they implement rules and procedures that make our jobs a lot harder.

pros: The organization is recognized and respected for its significant contributions to the disease
cons: Bullying from management was a recurring issue (specifically degrading comments, yelling, generally abusive behavior and tactics), and managers that participated in abusive behavior did not appear to face any scrutiny or consequences. As a result, there is extremely high turnover in the department both from people leaving voluntarily and being fired.

pros: Because of the progress that the CF Foundation is making, I feel like the work I'm doing is making a real contribution to improving the lives of those with cystic fibrosis.
cons: Some of the most negative, miserable and ungrateful volunteers I've ever experienced, no comp time for extra hours worked and there are a lot.

job_title: Service Learning Project Student in Las Vegas, NV
pros: It is a really good cause and a positive environment looking forward to find a cure. Adding tomorrows is what they are all about. It is also inspiring to work with those that have the disease because it motivates you to keep on going no matter what.
cons: Not really much since  I only stayed for a few months. I believe one of the things would be slight flaws in communication.

review_title: Great team of people working towards a great mission.
pros: Wonderful colleagues.  Casual and fun environment.  The mission of the organization and the volunteers are incredible.  Strong national partners.
cons: Many nights and weekends are expected to run events.  There is very little flex time offered.  The senior leadership doesn't always have a clear roll and there is not significant opportunity for professional growth.

review_title: Be careful of what you get yourself into!
pros: Benefits are good.  Associates are nice.
cons: Take caution before accepting a job in the Central Ohio Chapter. Very high turnover and extremely stressful.  Executive Director will appear nice at first but, becomes very demanding and will micro-micro manager her staff.  Four people gone under her leadership in one year.

review_title: Great benefits, out of touch employer
pros: Benefits are great for non-profit, 401k match, health, 3 weeks vacation, 12 sick days, summer hours are shorter (off at 3pm on fridays!)
cons: management has been here for almost 30 years and is stuck in one way of doing things, harder to introduce new ideas, no professional development happening

pros:
Great team members
Everyone really supports the organization's mission
Good work-life balance and supportive of WFH/flexible hours/etc depending on the team
cons:
Too many politics for a non-profit organization
Even though majority of staff is female, there are still many men in high level positions that are not always respectful to female staff
Not always sensitive to entry level staff concerns

pros: Mission driven organization with a track record of making significant medical breakthroughs in CF research. Trying to address shortcomings as an organization.
cons: Disconnect between field staff and policy makers.  Rolling out new initiatives without proper vetting.  Un-inspiring and hard to achieve bonus program.

pros: You can feel good knowing you are helping families that are trying to find a cure for themselves or their loved ones. This is not exclusive to this foundation, just a job in this field in general.
cons: They do not value their employees. They underpay compared to just about every other non profit out there. When promoting their employees, they will low ball the salary offer to the point where people have turned it down and left from being so insulted. If you earn an incentive they will do everything they can to justify why you didn't earn it to avoid having to reward you for your hard work. An ED mis-assign funds that belonged to one of my events in order to avoid having to pay out a bonus that was earned and there was nothing I could do about it. There is little to no oversight of the how the chapters are run so ED's can treat their employees however they see fit. Do your research to see how much turnover they have had, it is absolutely shocking in a terrible way. You will be expected to use your own finances for work expenses while traveling such has booking flights for required conferences, and they take no less than a month to reimburse you. This is absolutely not the industry standard. Other non profits either book the travel for you through their own internal travel agent, or you have your own company card and are NEVER expected to use your own personal fiances for work expenses. Basically this is the worst company I have ever worked for, do not work here. You will never feel more over worked, under valued, harassed, micro managed or underpaid in your life. The good vibes you get from helping families lasts for about 30 seconds after you interact with someone and then you go back to hating life. Basically, just don't work here.

pros: Mission so worthwhile and great community of engaged and caring families and volunteers.
cons: National office rife with politics. Execs tone deaf and cliquish. You are either "in" or "out" and often has nothing to do with performance. Sad.

review_title: No checks and balances for senior management creating an evil dictatorship senario.
pros: It's a great cause and you'll meet some very wonderful people. I could not speak more highly of the families and volunteers I worked with to help "cure cf".
cons:
The pay and benefits are average although once you are set at a salary there is not much advancement from there- you might get a 1-2% raise a year, if you're good...
Senior Management at the Northern New England Chapter uses threats and scare tatics to achieve goals and benchmarks. Weekly staff meetings were a screamfest and usually ended in tears. Everyone is in a constant state of fear and panic. If you try to sit down and "talk it out" with senior management at the chapter, you will be accused of not being good at your job and put you on a "performance improvement plan" which basically meant that if you retaliated again, you wouldl be fired. There were no checks and balances which allowed for an evil dictatorship senario to occur. Employees were scared to loose their job if they spoke out or contacted HR about the situation because "everything comes back to senior management." A number of the employees I worked with at the time were on anti-anxiety medication and my "ah-ha" moment came when I had a full-blown anxiety attack and was told i needed to start taking anti-anxiety medication as well. I cannot warn someone enough- don't take this job for any amount of money!

review_title: A wonderful place to work, great mission, leadership and culture. Very innovative and entrepreneurial culture
pros: Great mission, fair salaries, good benefits. A very innovative and entrepreneurial culture that is not very hierarchical. Easy to get things done
cons: Poor facilities at national office. We've outgrown our space and need to move to a new space. There are not enough conference rooms for people to have meetings.

pros: Their 401k plan is amazing, the cause is worthwhile. They are striving for a cure and making a huge difference in the community.
cons: Often unrealistic expectations on event revenue and time spent. You are expected to attend every single event that is put on by the chapter which effects quality of life in the long run.

review_title: As in any job especially one where fundrasing is so important to the bottom line, it can be tense.
pros: THe pros of the job is that it is providing valuable resources and research to cure Cystic Fibrosis.
cons: Alot of work that requires overtime and untraditional hours.

review_title: Had potential until true colors were revealed
pros: Mission, training, days off, dress code.
cons: Cliques in the chapters.  Sometimes bully atmosphere.  Absolutely no support from upper management.  It was like being in high school with a paycheck.

pros: A great cause and great support from supervisors.
cons: Long hours and it's hard to make the increasing goals every year.

review_title: Culture evolving to provide stronger staff support
pros: Feel very good about the difference I make through the work that I do. Executive Directors, Field Directors, and National Management are listening to field staff needs and providing requested support.
cons: Executive Directors need more accountability.

pros: Every day you go home feeling like you are actually contributing to something that is really making a difference, instead of working your boring 9-5 doing mindless computer and data entry work.
cons: Sometimes events can be long and the planning can be stressful but again, it's very fulfilling.

pros: Paid very well compared to other Non Profits.
cons: I worked there while they were going through a huge transition that I think is typical for non profits to cycle through.  From what I hear, it is a much better place to work now.  At the time, it was just a free for all with no direction.

review_title: High turnover due to mistreatment of employees
pros: To help fund the research that is curing CF and helping people struggling with this terrible disease.
cons: No life/work balance. They expect a lot of unpaid overtime. There is no recourse if there is a problem with a superior. They have very high turn over and it is very difficult to work constantly with new employees.

pros: Great mission, colleagues and management committed to the cause, and a new effort is underway to improve emplyee benefits.
cons: Understaffed in many departments, long hours, company is going through a lot of growing pains. There is also wide varation in the quality of upper level managers some are incredible some are horrible.

pros: Exciting place to work with new treatments and programs galore. Generally a lot of comradery, even across teams. Increased focused on employee satisfaction. Interesting and fulfilling work.
cons: Day to day satisfaction and opportunity depends a lot on manager, staff activities can feel forced. Lack of transparency with growth opportunities. Some departments are favorites.

pros: Great cause and families to work with, opportunity for growth and networking as well as a flexible schedule for meetings and field employees.
cons: better check and balance of management at a Chapter Level and enforced training schedule for new employees.

pros:
Lots of holidays off
Early dismissal Fridays in the summer 
Families are great to work with
cons:
Hard to grow in the company
Lack of communication from management and main office 
Very stressful when it does not have to be

pros: The whole staff is really nice, smart, and devoted to the cause. The organization is really prioritizing making CFF a great place to work.
cons: Location is way out in Bethesda

pros: -Fraud hotline means business if you need to use it.
cons:
-Terrible disconnect between national and local chapters.
-Not at all innovative
-Hired an exec. director to manage our office who was falsifying expense reports/not coming to work and national never figured it out. 
-Exec. Director would contact staff people at nights/wknds because they never came into the office. 
-No work/life balance
-Terrible place - stay away.

pros: The CFF cares about its mission, its people, and keeping with responsible financial stewardship.
cons: There is a power shift happening that may be tricky to navigate. Talented, worthwhile young professionals are being hired at the CFF at a rapid rate, and some older medical professionals are feeling the change.

review_title: A waste of time and talent
pros: The only pro of this organization is that it's mission is to help patients. Other than that, there are absolutely no pros.
cons: Where do I begin? The leadership has no direction and there is absolutely no communication between the C-suite and the rest of the staff. There is absolutely no room for innovation, growth of thinking outside the box. The mid level managers are ill prepared to manage the very young staff.

pros: Great mission, passionate and driven employees.
cons: Pay scale is totally out of whack. Pay for incoming employees is significantly higher than those who are promoted from within.

review_title: Good non-profit to work for, not much room for advancement unless you move to a different chapter
job_title: Director of Business Development in Norfolk, VA
pros: Decent pay, good work/life balance, purpose of work makes you feel good.
cons: Tough to advance unless you are OK with moving.  small staff in office.

review_title: Great place to work, long hours
pros: Great benefits, strong mission, outstanding volunteers, opportunities for growth available
cons: Long hours, many late nights depending on your role, strict policies

review_title: A very positive experience, where you feel good about working for a great cause.
pros: Great cause, very well run organization, clear job description, good work environment. Good emphasis on work-life balance.
cons: Unsure about salary competitiveness, no insurance coverage for the first three months of employment

pros: Great Foundation doing ground breaking work to cure CFF
cons: Salaries are low - and increases don't keep up with cost of living

review_title: Great people and place to work
pros: Great people. Feel valued and appreciated. CFF cares about their people. Excellent work/life balance.
cons: Looking forward to the new talent management and professional development projects in progress.

review_title: Good People helping a great cause
pros:
Good Work Environment 
Ability to telecommute
cons:
Management disorganized at times 
Sometimes lack of communication from those above leads to employees wasting time and doing double the work 
Pay isn't great but that is expected from a non-profit

pros:
Fabulous mission, working with top medical professionals.
Fair salaries.
cons: Slow to promote young people.

pros: organization is fiscally reponsible with donations-you konw where the money you raise is going and see results
cons: poor management and no proper chain of command to report problems

job_title: Development Director in Little Rock, AR
pros: Wonderful mission, chapters, and corporate office work well together, they care about their employees, always looking for ways to be better.
cons: Depending on the chapter, you may have a high workload.

pros: Great colleagues and internal department collaboration. Great benefits and 401K.
cons: Internal promotion is not the norm - external hires are more the trend. So high turnover and newly hired staff that require training.

pros: Fantastic mission, great leadership, amazing community
cons: Lack of understanding of the nuances of different regions and fundraising efforts; organization takes a "one size fits all" approach to events

review_title: The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation is a busy, robust highly effective place to work.
pros: Excellent team work. Amazing volunteers. Incredible progress in drug discovery. Proud to work with CFF.
cons: Long hours that include many nights and weekends.

pros: Small, close knit community, teamwork is huge and everyone is always willing to lend a helping hand even if it isn't their project
cons: Management is not as organized as it could be

pros: they spend a lot of time educating their and training their employees
cons: Success depends on the Executive Director of your Branch. All are not created equal

pros: Everyone works toward the mission, family like environment.
cons: Can't think of any.

pros: good education on research for a cure
cons: very limited budget to work with, continually relying on volunteers to do more and more.

pros: Production environment to work with. Dedicated team of hardworking individuals who's only goal is to find a cure for Cystic Fibrosis.
cons: There are not real cons to mention

pros: Good benefits and summer Fridays
cons: Executive leadership is very much a 'boys club', but things are getting better

job_title: Development Director in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: Education, and training. The members of the team work hard, but all in support of one another
cons: Large company with multiple layers of support

pros: A dedicated and committed team of individuals, working hard to find a cure for cystic fibrosis.
cons: Many long hours, however worth if for the mission of the organization.

pros: Great mission, friendly environment (at the national office), opportunities for advancement
cons: Shoestring budget and the constant pressure of Great Strides

pros: The company does a great job of offering training materials.
cons: Each office has it's own culture, as long as the Executive Director is great, the atmosphere is as well.

pros: Cause is important, people are fantastic, made lasting friendships, work hard, enjoy working at the fundraisers at Warner Bros.
cons: There are no cons at this time

review_title: Recommended if you're up for a challenge
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: There is always more work to do and opportunities to step up/stand out
cons: Small office; long hours including weekends

pros: Great team and environment. Learn a lot quickly and get a lot of responsibilities for an intern.
cons: Unpaid. Work night and weekends.

review_title: The CF Foundation does amazing things
job_title: Logistics Specialist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Work with great people all of the time
cons: The Foundation has a very corporate feel to it

pros:
interacting with CF families
Feeling good that you are helping people
fundraising event planning
cons:
demanding fundraising revenue totals
small teams
many events each year to meet revenue totals

job_title: Logistics Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: Great benefits, considerate management, reasonable salary and other compensation
cons: During event season you will put in long hours, and long weekends.

pros: You see the medical progress happening in real time, fun teams, energetic workplace, great benefits.
cons: Promotions can be slow coming.

pros: Great work - great purpose.
cons: Hard with the HQ in DC - a lot of red tape.

pros: Great place to work at. Lots of opportunities
cons: I have no complains about this foundation

pros: Good benefits. Company is always seeking to improve its customer and staff relations.
cons: Work-life balance can be improved

pros: Fantastic organization to wok for!
cons: It was an unpaid internship. However, very beneficial and lots of experience

pros: Cares About Our Employees, values work life balance and great benefit package
cons: Lack of career development and growth opportunity

pros: Great coworkers who care about your growth
cons: Can be quite bureaucratic and difficult to move upward

review_title: Awful 1st year w no ramp up time
pros: Volunteer core is critically important, dedicated  and supportive to cause
cons: Organization runs a very lean ship. Low overhead means little support and great expectations.  Management doesn't have a clue what it takes to support numerous events successfully.

review_title: Great cause, terrible management at local and national levels
pros: Great cause, wonderful families, dedicated volunteers
cons: Much disconnect with National offices, local senior management scared to "rock the boat", lack of respect for employees, too much emphasis on office time and "making budget" instead of looking at other sources of income

pros: Great opportunity to get into Development.
cons: Long hours at times.

pros: Making a difference in the lives of people with CF
cons: I have cons about this organizations

pros: Higher salary, great benefits vacations
cons: small offices with small drama

pros: you should work here its great
cons: no huge downsides, sometimes its very busy

review_title: Saying you care and actually caring are two different things!
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Bethesda, MD
pros: Great mission and great people at the lower levels.
cons: Management style is high school!

pros: Great families and worthy organization.
cons: long hours, low pay and ED and corporate does not care about the staff.

pros: Good cause,  families,  friendly board
cons: Management,  unrealistic expectations,  lots of pressure,  overburdened with compliance

pros: Good salary..slow raised with new system
cons: Toxic environment.  Competitive in office.  Bullying...high school environment

job_title: Consulting Services Trainee in Bethesda, MD
pros: Benefits, 401k matching, vacation, experience
cons: Lots of bullying, favorites and gossiping among managers
